content.question: A person in a boat wishes to cross a river from Point <math alttext="O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> to Point <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, as shown in the figure. The water has velocity <math alttext="v sub water, equals 5 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>water</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mtext> m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></math> in the positive <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction relative to the river bank, and the boat has a velocity of <math alttext="v sub boat, equals 10 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>boat</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mtext> m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></math> in the positive <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-direction relative to the water. Towards which point should the boat travel to reach Point <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and why?

choices.label: Toward Point <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> because the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-component of the boat’s velocity with respect to the water needs to be equal in magnitude to the velocity of the water.

Toward Point <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> because the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-component of the boat’s velocity with respect to the water needs to be equal in magnitude to the velocity of the water but in the opposite direction.

Toward Point <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> because the magnitude of the boat’s velocity with respect to the water is greater than the magnitude of the velocity of the water.

Toward Point <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> because the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-component of the boat’s velocity with respect to the water is not affected by the motion of the water.

content.answer: Toward Point <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> because the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-component of the boat’s velocity with respect to the water needs to be equal in magnitude to the velocity of the water but in the opposite direction.
